45457.base_text: I mean, the place looked like people should have lived there, but there was almost nothing around to prove it. Anonymous marks scuffed the walls, the odd piece of lint dotted the floor, but there were no height marks penciled on door frames, no piles of old magazines, no bright squares on dirty walls where pictures once hung. Not a single old candy wrapper or forgotten sock. I ran my hand across the wooden dowel and wondered who had put it there, if anyone had ever hung clothes from it.

45457.base_text: I’d poked my head into a room with an enormous old bureau—empty, like all the furniture—and a nook at the far end, a wooden dowel running along the top—like a doorless closet, maybe. I wandered over to investigate, hoping for a few dusty hangers, the remnants of an old calendar, some comforting sign of former human occupation. No such luck.

Niko spent a day in an extraordinary funk of fierce depression followed by an equally intense reversal, like he’d do from time to time, and I took advantage of his high to prod him into going to explore Downstairs. He took to this plan eagerly, and seemed pleased when I told him I’d been waiting so we could do it together. “Ryan,” he said fondly, “in an emergency, you know, you can do things without me. I’ll allow it.”

There was a sadness to it all. I thought of my first apartment, the one I’d moved into halfway through senior year of high school for reasons that—well. Reasons. It felt the same way, when I moved in and for most of the nine months I lived there: empty, anonymous. Faded, somehow. Less alive. I couldn’t spare any pieces of myself back then to lend it life, make it feel like a home. Maybe none of its earlier tenants had, either. A house without a soul. A year later I’d been glad to move into the dorms, for all their noise and smells and ill-repair, because at least there was no question that people had lived there.

45457.base_text: No—blinking, I realized it wasn’t that. When I’d turned back toward the doorway, it wasn’t there.

45457.base_text: For a second my heart pounded and my eyes darted around three blank white walls, pupils dilating in shock. I was trapped. There was no way out.

variants.text: For a second my heart pounded and my eyes darted around three blank white walls, pupils dilating in shock. I was trapped. There was no way out.

45457.base_text: I frowned. The doorway was on the other side of the room from the one I’d instinctively turned to. I thought I’d walked along the wall to get to the nook, that it and the door had been on the same side. But the door was on the opposite wall, diagonally across from me.

variants.text: I frowned. The doorway was on the other side of the room from the one I’d instinctively turned to. I thought I’d walked along the wall to get to the nook, that it and the door had been on the same side. But the door was on the opposite wall, diagonally across from me.

45457.base_text: And then as I jerked forward in shock, I saw my mistake. The inside of the door was the same color as the walls—even the knob had been painted over, inexplicably—and the angle of the room’s single light hid all shadows, so for a minute, from directly opposite, the door had turned invisible. A trick of perspective, and keyed up nerves.

45457.base_text: I closed my eyes, suddenly dizzy. I remembered keeping the faded white wall to my right as I crossed the carpet to the closet nook. But when I looked again, the door was still where it was, in the opposite corner.

45457.base_text: Obviously it hadn’t moved.
Niko hadn’t followed me in. I turned the white doorknob and pushed my head out into the hallway, called his name.

45457.base_text: Don’t see things that aren’t there. You fucking idiot.

45457.base_text: You’re doing it again.
Pushing away the uneasiness, I crossed diagonally across the carpet to the door, unable as I did to shake the sensation that I was tracing a different path than the one I’d walked coming in.

45457.base_text: There were maybe eighty steps. Other than that, and the fact that we were lighting our way with flashlights, they seemed like any other stairs in a house built during the Ford administration and sinking into senility. That same damn carpet. They must have bought up the whole factory.
“That is not cashmere,” I said, rolling my eyes. “Hey. Don’t wander off on me like that.”

45457.base_text: Niko had been excited to show me, but now he perched uneasily on the top step. I got out my flashlight and switched it on, pointing down. “Come on. Maybe there’s some answers down there.” He still looked hesitant. I put on my straightest face and my best P.I. voice. “Don’t you want to get… to the bottom of this?”

Other than that, and the fact that we were lighting our way with flashlights, they seemed like any other stairs in a house built during the Ford administration and sinking into senility. That same damn carpet. They must have bought up the whole factory.

When the stairs finally gave out, it was into another hallway, nearly identical to the ones above. This one felt a bit smaller, and the carpet a darker shade, looking more brown now, though maybe both impressions were a trick of the flashlights. Funny how much light influences your perception of spaces, of shapes. Colors. Everything, really.

45457.base_text: The wall sconces were still there, but no longer lit. Still no light switches anywhere.

45457.base_text: More rooms opened off this hall, though these had more variety. A few doors were locked, which we hadn’t encountered on the upper level. I searched the walls in vain for colored tacks with ripped corners of posters still attached, or even a crumpled gas station receipt. I mean it wasn’t like the place was sterile. Another room had a drain in the floor with stains running up to two big utility hookups on the wall, and the faint smells of dust and moths and yellowing wallpaper glue were everywhere. What was missing was anything personal.

45457.base_text: The weirdest room, though, was the kitchen. It was too big for a kitchen, for starters, and had too much stuff in it: too many oven hookups, too much haphazard ceiling ventilation, red-handled water valves everywhere, and a dozen jumbled stove tops with holes where the burners should be. There were parts of appliances but no whole ones: bundles of wiring, even a kitchen sink. Niko tried the faucet and we both were startled when water came out. It was like a half-assembled restaurant kitchen with all the equipment jumbled together, rather than a row of stoves here, a row of dishwashers there.

45457.base_text: Just the one door, too, and nothing nearby that might have been a dining room or pantry. A few doors down was a long, narrow room paved entirely in yellow bathroom tile and graying grout. A rust-pitted shower head, two immobile handles, and dirt-clogged drain clustered at one end, thirty feet away from the opposite wall.

45457.base_text: He shrugged.

There were maybe a hundred steps. Other than that, and the fact that we were lighting our way with flashlights, they seemed like any other stairs in a house built during the Nixon administration and sinking into senility. That same damn carpet. They must have bought up the whole factory.

“You get the feeling whoever built this place didn’t exactly know a lot about architecture?” Niko’s voice was hushed in a kind of reverence. “Everything down here’s off, you know? Like, who was that old lady in California who built that house with all the doors that went nowhere and fake hallways and everything?”

45457.base_text: Just the one door, too, and nothing nearby that might have been a dining room or pantry, though we did find a large, empty, low-ceilinged room a few doors down. “Not that you could get a dining table down here,” Niko mused. Same brown carpet, but no signs of anything to explain the room’s purpose: no ceiling bulb or place to attach one, not even a single electrical outlet.

45457.base_text: Sarah Winchester. I told him. Except her house is now an internationally famous tourist attraction. And this place was bigger.

45457.base_text: Someone should have known about this.

variants.text: Someone should have known about this.

45457.base_text: Niko was thinking along the same lines. “Seriously, though. Who the fuck built all this? And why? For what?”

45457.base_text: Why didn’t anyone know about this?
“No clue. But if there’s any explanation, it’s probably down here somewhere.” I even half-believed that, which felt nice.

45457.base_text: “I feel weird walking around a crazy person’s house.” His eyes darted around the empty room. “Not that I expect, like, pit traps and rotating blades. But it feels sort of… unsafe.”

45457.base_text: He kept glancing at me like he wanted me to say something that would make him feel better, to save him, so I tried my best like always. “You ever notice old horror movies have lots of really improbable architecture?” I babbled. “I want to meet some of those architects. Probably all dead now but I still want to grab them by their ghostly lapels and ask why the fuck they built all those crawlspaces and secret torture rooms and basements without proper lighting.”

45457.base_text: “Can we not talk about horror movies right now? Also, ghosts. Maybe just shut up, actually.” But he was grinning.

45457.base_text: We moved on.
The next door we tried was another locked one. For some reason, I knocked.

variants.text: The next door we tried was another locked one. For some reason, I knocked.

45457.base_text: “You’re freaking me out, man,” Niko said. He held the light under his face, washing it out to a ghostly tan as his eyes rolled up into his head. “Vreeaking meee owwwwt.”

variants.text: “You’re freaking me out, man,” Niko said. He held the light under his face, washing it out to a ghostly tan as his eyes rolled up into his head. “Vreeaking meee owwwwt.”

45457.base_text: “You would totally date undead me. Rotting flesh and all. Don’t pretend you wouldn’t.”

variants.text: “You would totally date undead me. Rotting flesh and all. Don’t pretend you wouldn’t.”

45457.base_text: “Why did you do that?” Niko hissed. I shrugged, smiling despite myself. But then a weird sensation came over me, like walking on someone’s grave. Because as silly as it was, we both couldn’t help waiting for a breath or two.

45457.base_text: “Attractive.”

A few more paces down the hallway, it opened into a pentagonal room, a closed door in each wall other than the one we’d entered through. We tried a few. Each door opened onto another staircase leading down.

variants.text: A few more paces down the hallway, it opened into a pentagonal room, a closed door in each wall other than the one we’d entered through. We tried a few. Each door opened onto another staircase leading down.

45457.base_text: Listening.
Isn’t that how that expression goes, walking on someone’s grave? Or is it someone walking on yours? No, that wouldn’t make sense. Never mind.

45457.base_text: There was no answer, of course.

45457.base_text: “Come on.” He grabbed my shoulder and propelled me down the hall. “Let’s keep going.” The rough of his hand shocked some courage back into me. My shoulder felt cool when he took the hand away.

45457.base_text: “But seriously,” Niko said, alarmed. “This cannot possibly be here. It doesn’t make sense.” He looked towards me, desperate. “Ryan, help.”

45457.base_text: “Okay,” I said, grasping at straws. “Maybe it’s like a whole underground network. All the houses in the neighborhood connected together. People used to smuggle drugs or something. Underground railroad.”

variants.text: “Okay,” I said, grasping at straws. “Maybe it’s like a whole underground network. All the houses in the neighborhood connected together. People used to smuggle drugs or something. Underground railroad.”

45457.base_text: A few more paces down the hallway, it opened into a six-sided room, a closed door in each wall other than the one we’d entered through. We tried a few. Each door opened onto another staircase leading down.

variants.text: A few more paces down the hallway, it opened into a six-sided room, a closed door in each wall other than the one we’d entered through. We tried a few. Each door opened onto another staircase leading down.

45457.base_text: “Decor’s too new,” he countered. “And we haven’t found any other stairs back up.”

variants.text: “Decor’s too new,” he countered. “And we haven’t found any other stairs back up.”

45457.base_text: “Bomb shelter. Last owner decided to modernize. Dreamt of turning it into the ultimate student housing complex. Collapsed from construction debt before he could get rich off desperate kids willing to live in windowless asbestos-lined death traps.”

variants.text: “Bomb shelter. Last owner decided to modernize. Dreamt of turning it into the ultimate student housing complex. Collapsed from construction debt before he could get rich off desperate kids willing to live in windowless asbestos-lined death traps.”

45457.base_text: I peered down one of the dark stairwells, frustrated. It bothered me that we might be so close to figuring this out. The next door might open onto something that explained it all.

variants.text: I peered down one of the dark stairwells, frustrated. It bothered me that we might be so close to figuring this out. The next door might open onto something that explained it all.

45457.base_text: “Secret government lab, then. Long-term research on the effects of interior decorating on lonely housewives. Program got relocated to Washington along with all the lonely housewives when Clinton was elected.”

variants.text: “Secret government lab, then. Long-term research on the effects of interior decorating on lonely housewives. Program got relocated to Washington along with all the lonely housewives when Clinton was elected.”

45457.base_text: He shook his head. “Let’s go back, man. I don’t like this. Something’s not right.”

variants.text: He shook his head. “Let’s go back, man. I don’t like this. Something’s not right.”

45457.base_text: And an undercurrent of excitement cut through the tinge of fear. This was fun. We were exploring. On a quest together.

variants.text: And an undercurrent of excitement cut through the tinge of fear. This was fun. We were exploring. On a quest together.

45457.base_text: I didn’t want it to end.

variants.text: I didn’t want it to end.

45457.base_text: I talked him into it. After all there was nothing dangerous down here: it wasn’t like exploring an abandoned mine shaft. Everything was in perfect repair even if no one seemed to have been here for years.

variants.text: I talked him into it. After all there was nothing dangerous down here: it wasn’t like exploring an abandoned mine shaft. Everything was in perfect repair even if no one seemed to have been here for years.

45457.base_text: “It can’t go on forever,” I said. “And whatever’s deepest down will be most interesting, right?”

variants.text: “It can’t go on forever,” I said. “And whatever’s deepest down will be most interesting, right?”

45457.base_text: “Solid enough,” Niko said, poking at the wall. “Just not a lot of, you know. Ambiance.”

variants.text: “Solid enough,” Niko said, poking at the wall. “Just not a lot of, you know. Ambiance.”

45457.base_text: Big as it was, it was only architecture.

variants.text: Big as it was, it was only architecture.

45457.base_text: After four or five weird angled twists the stairs ended, opening up into another corridor. Everything felt exactly the same, despite being stories deeper underground. It was as bland and anonymous as office space in a skyscraper.

45457.base_text: The staircase we picked dropped down for a few dozen steps, then turned at a weird angle and dropped some more. It wasn’t necessarily smaller but felt more claustrophobic. Maybe that was my brain reminding me how deep underground we must be getting. At most of the landings a new hall branched off, each at a different angle. We kept going down.

45457.base_text: There were more doors.

After four or five weird angled twists the stairs ended, opening up into another corridor. This one felt different, though I couldn’t put my finger on why. The texture of the carpet, maybe, or something changed in the wall paneling. Like a new decorator working to the same plans.

variants.text: After four or five weird angled twists the stairs ended, opening up into another corridor. This one felt different, though I couldn’t put my finger on why. The texture of the carpet, maybe, or something changed in the wall paneling. Like a new decorator working to the same plans.

45457.base_text: We shuffled past them, flashlights glinting off doorknobs and—there was a difference—instead of the wall sconces, fake candelabra now. You know the ones, with those awful faux-candles that flicker orange and don’t fool anyone? They weren’t lit now, anyway.

variants.text: We shuffled past them, flashlights glinting off doorknobs and—there was a difference—instead of the wall sconces, fake candelabra now. You know the ones, with those awful faux-candles that flicker orange and don’t fool anyone? They weren’t lit now, anyway.

45457.base_text: We stopped less to try side doors now, eager to get to the end of the hall, or the end of something, at least. Find some answers.

variants.text: We stopped less to try side doors now, eager to get to the end of the hall, or the end of something, at least. Find some answers.

45457.base_text: For a long stretch there were no doors at all, just wood paneling, so that when we did come to another door it was a relief, like exhaling held breath. Niko tried it, and it swung open onto a room unlike anything we’d seen so far.

variants.text: For a long stretch there were no doors at all, just wood paneling, so that when we did come to another door it was a relief, like exhaling held breath. Niko tried it, and it swung open onto a room like nothing we’d seen so far.

45457.base_text: It’s hard to explain the quiet. It felt complete in a deeper way than absence of sound. Like we were far away from anything that made noise, other than us. I guess we were.

variants.text: It’s hard to explain the quiet. It felt complete in a deeper way than absence of sound. Like we were far away from anything that made noise, other than us. I guess we were.

45457.base_text: It was concrete and tall, with rounded corners at the bottom. The ceiling was higher than the walls, like we were in a pit dug into a bigger room. In the center of the concrete floor was a drain.

variants.text: It was concrete and tall, with rounded corners at the bottom. The ceiling was higher than the walls, like we were in a pit dug into a bigger room. In the center of the concrete floor was a drain.

45457.base_text: Niko, intrigued, grabbed the bottom of a short ladder that ended around shoulder-height and pulled himself up to the top of the pit, flashlight swinging wildly. I clung to mine, keeping it steady like a candle I was afraid would blow out.

variants.text: Niko, intrigued, grabbed the bottom of a short ladder that ended around shoulder-height and pulled himself up to the top of the pit, flashlight swinging wildly. I clung to mine, keeping it steady like a candle I was afraid would blow out.

45457.base_text: I felt afraid, without quite knowing why.

variants.text: I felt afraid, without quite knowing why.

45457.base_text: I felt afraid, without knowing why.

variants.text: I felt afraid, without knowing why.

45457.base_text: He shined his light back down at me. “Yep,” he said, “it’s a swimming pool.”

variants.text: He shined his light back down at me. “Yep,” he said, “it’s a swimming pool.”

45457.base_text: That made sense, by some incredibly loose definition. “What’s up there?”

variants.text: That made sense, by some incredibly loose definition. “What’s up there?”

45457.base_text: He turned away from the lip, moved out of sight. Patterns of light swam across the ceiling as he swung the flashlight around. Something rattled. “Another kitchen.” His voice bounced oddly off the rounded concrete. “This one’s all furnished, though.”

variants.text: He turned away from the lip, moved out of sight. Patterns of light swam across the ceiling as he swung the flashlight around. Something rattled. “Another kitchen.” His voice bounced oddly off the rounded concrete. “This one’s all furnished, though.”

45457.base_text: I was getting more and more unsettled, unaccountably so. “Any more doors?”

variants.text: I was getting more and more unsettled, unaccountably so. “Any more doors?”

45457.base_text: The door we’d come through, I noticed, was the same as all the others: cheap particle board, regular brass-plated knob. Not especially waterproof. I bent down, pushed it shut. Sure enough, there was a gap between it and the top of the carpet outside. Like you’d expect for any regular door not, you know, at the bottom of a swimming pool.

45457.base_text: Something rattled up there, wood scraping wood. “There’s silverware in these drawers,” he called, as if he hadn’t heard me. “Cups in the cabinets too. Super seventies.”

variants.text: Something rattled up there, wood scraping wood. “There’s silverware in these drawers,” he called, as if he hadn’t heard me. “Cups in the cabinets too. Super seventies.”

45457.base_text: The reflections of light moved to and fro, like something alive. “Nope. No way in or out except through the pool. And there’s no place to sit and eat, either.” He paused. More scuffling. “Funny. The fridge is locked. Like, there’s a keyhole on the fridge and you can’t open it. Who does that?”

45457.base_text: “Hey, Niko?” I straightened up, keeping my voice steady. “Let’s go back.” I wanted to add I don’t like this or maybe I want to get the hell out of here right now, but some irrational fear gripped me that if I showed any weakness, he’d be the one who wanted to keep going down.

variants.text: “Hey, Niko?” I straightened up, keeping my voice steady. “Let’s go back.” I wanted to add I don’t like this or maybe I want to get the hell out of here right now, but some irrational fear gripped me that if I showed any weakness, he’d be the one who wanted to keep going down.

45457.base_text: Going deeper.

His voice was starting to seem unreal. I felt how tenuous a connection I had to him: a voice, the glints of his flashlight on the ceiling above the empty pool. Echoes and shadows. The distance between us seemed vast and growing vaster, maybe already unbridgeable.

45457.base_text: And then. Maybe I imagined this, between the weird echoes of that concrete pool bottom and the nerves I’d worked up. But I thought I heard muffled voices. Faint. Coming through the wall.

variants.text: And then. Maybe I imagined this, between the weird echoes of that concrete pool bottom and the nerves I’d worked up. But I thought I heard muffled voices. Faint. Coming through the wall.

45457.base_text: I remembered lying in bed as a kid, waiting to be tucked in, and the person I loved most in the world vanishing, between one blink and the next.

45457.base_text: Coming from the other side of the closed door back out.

45462.base_text: The hallway had twisted a few more times, Niko said, then split again. I’d felt fine after a good night’s sleep, but neither of us seemed in any hurry to head back Downstairs the next day. It might seem odd that we didn’t go back down there to map the whole thing out right away. I can’t really explain it, unless Niko was already feeling the same irrational foreboding as me.

But that was all academic while I was puking my guts out over a toilet bowl, and for much of the awful day after. Still, it might seem odd that we didn’t go back down there to map the whole thing out right away. I can’t really explain it, unless Niko was already feeling the same irrational foreboding as me.

45462.base_text: Anyway. I knew there wasn’t really anything down there, Downstairs, and as the memory faded so did the lingering terror. Replacing it was a giddy sensation like having too much Halloween candy. There was a whole huge secret basement under our house that only we knew about. It felt good to have another secret. Another code in our personal dictionary, something only for us.

I’ve always spooked too easy. Horror movies, for instance, were an absolute no-go. I’d realized this at some point in high school when they were still a kind of macho rite of passage. One of the last ones I watched was a terrible direct-to-video job about a creature that lived in the woods and hunted down the teenagers who kept blithely wandering in. When you finally saw the monster it was a huge let-down—terrible make-up on an even worse actor. But before you saw it on screen, you heard it, and the movie’s whole gimmick, its thing, was that the creature would parrot back anything said to it, in the original voice, flawless. It wasn’t clear if it understood the words, or just mindlessly mimicked the sound. But while it was slaughtering each hapless cheerleader it would repeat her terrified cries for help back to her, perfectly. Would keep screaming in her voice even after she’d died.

45462.base_text: Niko was terrible at secrets. By next afternoon, all the other housemates had seen Downstairs too, as well as a couple of his lacrosse buddies and one or two of his closest board game buddies. (He’d made a point of changing majors and hobbies once a quarter for the past year, while continuing to swear up and down to his immigrant parents he was still majoring in Economics.) I tried not to take the betrayal personally.

That concept settled into my brain and ate away at me for weeks, though I couldn’t explain why it was so terrifying. Why should the worst thing to hear from a dark woods at night be not snarls or growls or witchy laughter, but your own voice, yourself? And yet it was. A few weeks later I jerked awake well after midnight certain something was standing in the shadows of my room, and as I reached out frantic for my lamp I knocked it off the nightstand and it crashed to the floor, the bulb shattering with a tinkle, and I stupidly called out “Is someone there?” and as I did I realized if I heard it repeated back to me from the shadows it would be the end of me, a clean break through my sanity, even if it was a joke or a prank or a hallucination, and as I clutched my blanket too terrified to go to the light switch on the wall I prayed, pleaded with my brimful imagination not to choose that moment to overflow, to improvise, to believe in things that weren’t really there, like it had each time I’d read too much into smiles or gestures, each time I’d watched vivid movies play in my head sprung from single sentences in books or looked at clouds and seen, really seen, fantastic shapes in them, and I’m pretty sure that was the exact moment I decided horror movies weren’t for me.

(He’d made a point of changing majors and hobbies once a quarter for the past year, while continuing to swear up and down to his immigrant parents he was still majoring in Economics.) I tried not to take the betrayal personally, but kind of failed.

Niko was terrible at secrets. By next afternoon, all the other housemates had seen Downstairs too, as well as a couple of his baseball buddies and one or two of his closest philosophy buddies. (He’d made a point of changing majors and hobbies once a quarter for the past year, while continuing to swear up and down to his immigrant parents he was still majoring in Economics.) I tried not to take the betrayal personally, but kind of failed.

Niko was terrible at keeping secrets. By next afternoon, all the other housemates had seen Downstairs too, as well as a couple of his baseball buddies and one or two of his closest philosophy buddies. (He’d made a point of changing majors and hobbies once a quarter for the past year, while continuing to swear up and down to his immigrant parents he was still majoring in Economics.) I tried not to take the betrayal personally, but kind of failed.

Anyway. I knew there wasn’t really anything down there, Downstairs, and as the memory faded so did the lingering terror. Replacing it was a giddy sensation like having too much candy. There was a whole huge secret basement under our house that only we knew about. It felt good to have a secret. Another code in our personal dictionary, something only for us.

45462.base_text: Anyway. I knew there wasn’t really anything down there, Downstairs, and as the memory faded so did the lingering terror. Replacing it was a giddy sensation like having too much candy. There was a whole huge secret basement under our house that only we knew about. It felt good to have another secret. Another code in our personal dictionary, something only for us.

Anyway. I knew there wasn’t really anything down there, Downstairs, and as the hangover faded so did the lingering terror. Replacing it was a giddy sensation like having too much Halloween candy. There was a whole huge secret basement under our house that only we knew about, Niko and I. It felt good to have another secret. Another code in our personal dictionary, something only for us.

But the strange thing was that no one seemed much interested. Everyone agreed Downstairs was a cool find, and made for a sick hangout spot, but no one cared to venture too far outside the big central room, or spend too much time down there. Everyone other than Niko and I would get bored, start talking about other things, eventually drift back upstairs to whatever they’d been doing before.

45462.base_text: Odd, in hindsight.

We did end up dusting off a couple of the old couches down there, and moving down a half-dozen boxes of my records, and made the Big Room available as a kind of secondary hangout space, quieter than the crowded front room with the TV and people always coming and going. Some of the empty rooms off the big one turned into overflow storage for everyone’s miscellaneous shit, but remained otherwise unoccupied. An old bandmate of Niko’s who’d dropped out of college to start an art collective got really excited about free studio space, moved in a bunch of junk for some unfinished sculptural masterpiece (“I’m going to need at least twice this many fishbowls,” she apologized), then never came back again. Maybe it was a con.

45462.base_text: “Man, y’all could live rent-free,” one of Niko’s ex-bandmates said one night while we were down there, poking her head into another lonely room. “Let these out to those poor engineering frosh. They don’t see no daylight anyway.”

45462.base_text: “Yeah,” I said, “except everyone would have to come in and out through my bed.”

45462.base_text: Sometimes, I did too.

“I mean they wouldn’t walk directly over you,” she explained, patting a patronizing hand on my shoulder. “Even though I know that kind of sad sack white boy victim scene is right up your alley. You ask nice, they’ll just gently kick you out of the way.”

45462.base_text: Maybe because of that, definitely because of day-to-day distractions, and, okay, because I was sulking, more than a week passed before we got around to scoping out the place in depth. Niko spent a day in an extraordinary funk of fierce depression followed by an equally intense reversal, like he’d do from time to time, and I took advantage of his high to prod him into going to explore the rest of Downstairs. He took to this plan eagerly, and seemed pleased when I told him I’d been waiting so we could do it together. “Ryan,” he said fondly, “in an emergency, you know, you can do things without me. I’ll allow it.”

No one did end up moving down there. Zero natural light is kind of a downer, even for well-adjusted people. Niko made some noise about bringing a girl down sometime. (“Dude, it’s a secret make-out lair. You’re doing college wrong if you don’t get some action down there.”) But we both knew he wouldn’t actually do it. It was too quiet, for one thing.

45462.base_text: Once, on a bad day, I’d been sitting on the roof of the sciences tower, crying. It was supposed to be off-limits but we’d figured out how to get up there one night: another shared secret. Keeping me company was a rusted-out telescope, a hulking cube of HVAC, and a ten-story drop. I wasn’t seriously considering anything but took some morbid comfort from having the option at hand.

45462.base_text: It also felt forbidden, somehow, but not in like a sexy rule-breaking kind of way. Being down there had the vague flavor of trespassing, the kind where you’re not going to get away with it and it’ll go bad for you when you get caught. Sneaking into a restricted area at the airport; busting into Area 51. I mean it was our house, right? But Downstairs didn’t feel like ours. Enough laughter or booze or noise and the feeling went away, or at least buried itself somewhere deep, where you’d hardly ever notice it.

I’ll allow it.”

45462.base_text: We sat there looking down the gently sloping hill of campus, its landmarks and avenues made abstract and manageable. A miniature city you could wrap your arms around, contain. Everyone in the world tiny, except for us.

45462.base_text: It felt a lot like the rooftop. Forbidden, charged with risk, with dangers from within and without. But also with a tense electricity of connection. A bond. Like if I went down alone, he’d know I was there. And vice versa.

45462.base_text: We’d grabbed flashlights in case of dark corners or burnt-out bulbs, but didn’t need them. Every hall was lit by those cheerful bright wall sconces, and most of the side rooms had a single bare bulb in the center of the ceiling. But it was the damnedest thing. We couldn’t find an end to the place. We picked one hallway and wandered around for maybe fifteen minutes, through T-junctions and ninety-degree corners, past dozens of doors and half-furnished rooms. The same wood-paneled walls, seventies carpet, and wall sconces were everywhere. Downstairs was aggressively bland but disturbingly unbounded. It went from weird to surreal to sort of frightening, how much of it there was. And this was just one of the five hallways off the central room.

45462.base_text: I mean, the place looked like people should have lived there, but there was almost nothing around to prove it. Anonymous marks scuffed the walls, the odd piece of lint dotted the floor, but there were no height marks penciled on door frames, no piles of old magazines, no bright squares on dirty walls where pictures once hung. Not a single old candy wrapper or forgotten sock. I ran my hand across the wooden dowel and wondered who had put it there, if anyone had ever hung clothes from it.

I wandered over to investigate, hoping for a few dusty hangers, the remnants of an old calendar, some comforting sign of former human occupation. No such luck.

I’ll allow it.”

There was a sadness to it all. I thought of my first apartment, the one I’d moved into halfway through senior year of high school for reasons that—well. Reasons. It felt the same way, when I moved in and for most of the nine months I lived there: empty, anonymous. Faded, somehow. Less alive. I couldn’t spare any pieces of myself back then to lend it life, make it feel like a home. Maybe none of its earlier tenants had, either. A house without a soul. A year later I’d been glad to move into the dorms, for all their noise and smells and ill-repair, because at least there was no question that people had lived there.

45462.base_text: And then as I jerked forward in shock, I saw my mistake. The inside of the door was the same color as the walls—even the knob had been painted over, inexplicably—and the angle of the room’s single light hid all shadows, so for a minute, from directly opposite, the door had turned invisible. A trick of perspective, and keyed up nerves.

45462.base_text: There were maybe eighty steps. Other than that, and the fact that we were lighting our way with flashlights, they seemed like any other stairs in a house built during the Ford administration and sinking into senility. That same damn carpet. They must have bought up the whole factory.
“That is not cashmere,” I said, rolling my eyes. “Hey. Don’t wander off on me like that.”

45462.base_text: I didn’t want to admit how spooked I’d been, and thought I’d done a good job hiding it, but of course he knew me better than that. He stared into me and seeing those emerald eyes full of concern was enough to melt my fear, transmute it into something infinitely better.

When the stairs finally gave out, it was into another hallway, nearly identical to the ones above. This one felt a bit smaller, and the carpet a darker shade, looking more brown now, though maybe both impressions were a trick of the flashlights. Funny how much light influences your perception of spaces, of shapes. Colors. Everything, really.

45462.base_text: The wall sconces were still there, but no longer lit. Still no light switches anywhere.

45462.base_text: More rooms opened off this hall, though these had more variety. A few doors were locked, which we hadn’t encountered on the upper level. I searched the walls in vain for colored tacks with ripped corners of posters still attached, or even a crumpled gas station receipt. I mean it wasn’t like the place was sterile. Another room had a drain in the floor with stains running up to two big utility hookups on the wall, and the faint smells of dust and moths and yellowing wallpaper glue were everywhere. What was missing was anything personal.

45462.base_text: The weirdest room, though, was the kitchen. It was too big for a kitchen, for starters, and had too much stuff in it: too many oven hookups, too much haphazard ceiling ventilation, red-handled water valves everywhere, and a dozen jumbled stove tops with holes where the burners should be. There were parts of appliances but no whole ones: bundles of wiring, even a kitchen sink. Niko tried the faucet and we both were startled when water came out. It was like a half-assembled restaurant kitchen with all the equipment jumbled together, rather than a row of stoves here, a row of dishwashers there.

A few doors down was a long, narrow room paved entirely in yellow bathroom tile and graying grout. A rust-pitted shower head, two immobile handles, and dirt-clogged drain clustered at one end, thirty feet away from the opposite wall.

45462.base_text: He shrugged.

There were maybe a hundred steps. Other than that, and the fact that we were lighting our way with flashlights, they seemed like any other stairs in a house built during the Nixon administration and sinking into senility. That same damn carpet. They must have bought up the whole factory.

“You get the feeling whoever built this place didn’t exactly know a lot about architecture?” Niko’s voice was hushed in a kind of reverence. “Everything down here’s off, you know? Like, who was that old lady in California who built that house with all the doors that went nowhere and fake hallways and everything?”

Same brown carpet, but no signs of anything to explain the room’s purpose: no ceiling bulb or place to attach one, not even a single electrical outlet.

45462.base_text: Why didn’t anyone know about this?
“No clue. But if there’s any explanation, it’s probably down here somewhere.” I even half-believed that, which felt nice.

45462.base_text: He kept glancing at me like he wanted me to say something that would make him feel better, to save him, so I tried my best like always. “You ever notice old horror movies have lots of really improbable architecture?” I babbled. “I want to meet some of those architects. Probably all dead now but I still want to grab them by their ghostly lapels and ask why the fuck they built all those crawlspaces and secret torture rooms and basements without proper lighting.”

45462.base_text: We moved on.
The next door we tried was another locked one. For some reason, I knocked.

45462.base_text: “You’re freaking me out, man,” Niko said. He held the light under his face, washing it out to a ghostly tan as his eyes rolled up into his head. “Vreeaking meee owwwwt.”

variants.text: “You’re freaking me out, man,” Niko said. He held the light under his face, washing it out to a ghostly tan as his eyes rolled up into his head. “Vreeaking meee owwwwt.”

45462.base_text: “You would totally date undead me. Rotting flesh and all. Don’t pretend you wouldn’t.”

variants.text: “You would totally date undead me. Rotting flesh and all. Don’t pretend you wouldn’t.”

45462.base_text: “Why did you do that?” Niko hissed. I shrugged, smiling despite myself. But then a weird sensation came over me, like walking on someone’s grave. Because as silly as it was, we both couldn’t help waiting for a breath or two.

45462.base_text: “Attractive.”

A few more paces down the hallway, it opened into a pentagonal room, a closed door in each wall other than the one we’d entered through. We tried a few. Each door opened onto another staircase leading down.

45462.base_text: Listening.

45462.base_text: “Okay,” I said, grasping at straws. “Maybe it’s like a whole underground network. All the houses in the neighborhood connected together. People used to smuggle drugs or something. Underground railroad.”

45462.base_text: “Bomb shelter. Last owner decided to modernize. Dreamt of turning it into the ultimate student housing complex. Collapsed from construction debt before he could get rich off desperate kids willing to live in windowless asbestos-lined death traps.”

variants.text: “Bomb shelter. Last owner decided to modernize. Dreamt of turning it into the ultimate student housing complex. Collapsed from construction debt before he could get rich off desperate kids willing to live in windowless asbestos-lined death traps.”

45462.base_text: I peered down one of the dark stairwells, frustrated. It bothered me that we might be so close to figuring this out. The next door might open onto something that explained it all.

variants.text: I peered down one of the dark stairwells, frustrated. It bothered me that we might be so close to figuring this out. The next door might open onto something that explained it all.

45462.base_text: “Secret government lab, then. Long-term research on the effects of interior decorating on lonely housewives. Program got relocated to Washington along with all the lonely housewives when Clinton was elected.”

45462.base_text: He shook his head. “Let’s go back, man. I don’t like this. Something’s not right.”

45462.base_text: And an undercurrent of excitement cut through the tinge of fear. This was fun. We were exploring. On a quest together.

45462.base_text: I didn’t want it to end.

variants.text: I didn’t want it to end.

45462.base_text: I talked him into it. After all there was nothing dangerous down here: it wasn’t like exploring an abandoned mine shaft. Everything was in perfect repair even if no one seemed to have been here for years.

variants.text: I talked him into it. After all there was nothing dangerous down here: it wasn’t like exploring an abandoned mine shaft. Everything was in perfect repair even if no one seemed to have been here for years.

45462.base_text: “It can’t go on forever,” I said. “And whatever’s deepest down will be most interesting, right?”

variants.text: “It can’t go on forever,” I said. “And whatever’s deepest down will be most interesting, right?”

45462.base_text: “Solid enough,” Niko said, poking at the wall. “Just not a lot of, you know. Ambiance.”

variants.text: “Solid enough,” Niko said, poking at the wall. “Just not a lot of, you know. Ambiance.”

45462.base_text: Big as it was, it was only architecture.

variants.text: Big as it was, it was only architecture.

45462.base_text: After four or five weird angled twists the stairs ended, opening up into another corridor. Everything felt exactly the same, despite being stories deeper underground. It was as bland and anonymous as office space in a skyscraper.

variants.text: After four or five weird angled twists the stairs ended, opening up into another corridor. Everything felt exactly the same, despite being stories deeper underground. It was as bland and anonymous as office space in a skyscraper.

45462.base_text: The staircase we picked dropped down for a few dozen steps, then turned at a weird angle and dropped some more. It wasn’t necessarily smaller but felt more claustrophobic. Maybe that was my brain reminding me how deep underground we must be getting. At most of the landings a new hall branched off, each at a different angle. We kept going down.

variants.text: The staircase we picked dropped down for a few dozen steps, then turned at a weird angle and dropped some more. It wasn’t necessarily smaller but felt more claustrophobic. Maybe that was my brain reminding me how deep underground we must be getting. At most of the landings a new hall branched off, each at a different angle. We kept going down.

45462.base_text: I talked him into it. It didn’t take that much doing. He felt the same pull as me. And there was nothing dangerous down here: it wasn’t like exploring an abandoned mine shaft. Everything was in perfect repair even if no one seemed to have been here for years.

variants.text: I talked him into it. It didn’t take that much doing. He felt the same pull as me. And there was nothing dangerous down here: it wasn’t like exploring an abandoned mine shaft. Everything was in perfect repair even if no one seemed to have been here for years.

45462.base_text: There were more doors.

After four or five weird angled twists the stairs ended, opening up into another corridor. This one felt different, though I couldn’t put my finger on why. The texture of the carpet, maybe, or something changed in the wall paneling. Like a new decorator working to the same plans.

variants.text: After four or five weird angled twists the stairs ended, opening up into another corridor. This one felt different, though I couldn’t put my finger on why. The texture of the carpet, maybe, or something changed in the wall paneling. Like a new decorator working to the same plans.

45462.base_text: We shuffled past them, flashlights glinting off doorknobs and—there was a difference—instead of the wall sconces, fake candelabra now. You know the ones, with those awful faux-candles that flicker orange and don’t fool anyone? They weren’t lit now, anyway.

variants.text: We shuffled past them, flashlights glinting off doorknobs and—there was a difference—instead of the wall sconces, fake candelabra now. You know the ones, with those awful faux-candles that flicker orange and don’t fool anyone? They weren’t lit now, anyway.

45462.base_text: We stopped less to try side doors now, eager to get to the end of the hall, or the end of something, at least. Find some answers.

variants.text: We stopped less to try side doors now, eager to get to the end of the hall, or the end of something, at least. Find some answers.

45462.base_text: For a long stretch there were no doors at all, just wood paneling, so that when we did come to another door it was a relief, like exhaling held breath. Niko tried it, and it swung open onto a room unlike anything we’d seen so far.

variants.text: For a long stretch there were no doors at all, just wood paneling, so that when we did come to another door it was a relief, like exhaling held breath. Niko tried it, and it swung open onto a room unlike anything we’d seen so far.

45462.base_text: For a long stretch there were no doors at all, just wood paneling, so that when we did come to another door it was a relief, like exhaling held breath. Niko tried it, and it swung open onto a room like nothing we’d seen so far.

variants.text: For a long stretch there were no doors at all, just wood paneling, so that when we did come to another door it was a relief, like exhaling held breath. Niko tried it, and it swung open onto a room like nothing we’d seen so far.

45462.base_text: It’s hard to explain the quiet. It felt complete in a deeper way than absence of sound. Like we were far away from anything that made noise, other than us. I guess we were.

variants.text: It’s hard to explain the quiet. It felt complete in a deeper way than absence of sound. Like we were far away from anything that made noise, other than us. I guess we were.

45462.base_text: It was concrete and tall, with rounded corners at the bottom. The ceiling was higher than the walls, like we were in a pit dug into a bigger room. In the center of the concrete floor was a drain.

variants.text: It was concrete and tall, with rounded corners at the bottom. The ceiling was higher than the walls, like we were in a pit dug into a bigger room. In the center of the concrete floor was a drain.

45462.base_text: Niko, intrigued, grabbed the bottom of a short ladder that ended around shoulder-height and pulled himself up to the top of the pit, flashlight swinging wildly. I clung to mine, keeping it steady like a candle I was afraid would blow out.

variants.text: Niko, intrigued, grabbed the bottom of a short ladder that ended around shoulder-height and pulled himself up to the top of the pit, flashlight swinging wildly. I clung to mine, keeping it steady like a candle I was afraid would blow out.

45462.base_text: I felt afraid, without quite knowing why.

variants.text: I felt afraid, without quite knowing why.

45462.base_text: I felt afraid, without knowing why.

variants.text: I felt afraid, without knowing why.

45462.base_text: He shined his light back down at me. “Yep,” he said, “it’s a swimming pool.”

variants.text: He shined his light back down at me. “Yep,” he said, “it’s a swimming pool.”

45462.base_text: That made sense, by some incredibly loose definition. “What’s up there?”

variants.text: That made sense, by some incredibly loose definition. “What’s up there?”

45462.base_text: He turned away from the lip, moved out of sight. Patterns of light swam across the ceiling as he swung the flashlight around. Something rattled. “Another kitchen.” His voice bounced oddly off the rounded concrete. “This one’s all furnished, though.”

variants.text: He turned away from the lip, moved out of sight. Patterns of light swam across the ceiling as he swung the flashlight around. Something rattled. “Another kitchen.” His voice bounced oddly off the rounded concrete. “This one’s all furnished, though.”

45462.base_text: I was getting more and more unsettled, unaccountably so. “Any more doors?”

variants.text: I was getting more and more unsettled, unaccountably so. “Any more doors?”

45462.base_text: The door we’d come through, I noticed, was the same as all the others: cheap particle board, regular brass-plated knob. Not especially waterproof. I bent down, pushed it shut. Sure enough, there was a gap between it and the top of the carpet outside. Like you’d expect for any regular door not, you know, at the bottom of a swimming pool.

variants.text: The door we’d come through, I noticed, was the same as all the others: cheap particle board, regular brass-plated knob. Not especially waterproof. I bent down, pushed it shut. Sure enough, there was a gap between it and the top of the carpet outside. Like you’d expect for any regular door not, you know, at the bottom of a swimming pool.

45462.base_text: Something rattled up there, wood scraping wood. “There’s silverware in these drawers,” he called, as if he hadn’t heard me. “Cups in the cabinets too. Super seventies.”

variants.text: Something rattled up there, wood scraping wood. “There’s silverware in these drawers,” he called, as if he hadn’t heard me. “Cups in the cabinets too. Super seventies.”

45462.base_text: The reflections of light moved to and fro, like something alive. “Nope. No way in or out except through the pool. And there’s no place to sit and eat, either.” He paused. More scuffling. “Funny. The fridge is locked. Like, there’s a keyhole on the fridge and you can’t open it. Who does that?”

45462.base_text: Something rattled up there, wood scraping wood. “There’s silverware in these drawers,” he called, as if he hadn’t heard me. “Cups in the cabinets too. Super seventies. I think Barbarella had these cups.”

Sure enough, there was a gap between it and the top of the carpet. Like you’d expect for any regular door not, you know, at the bottom of a swimming pool.

Sure enough, there was a gap between it and the top of the carpet. Like you’d expect for any regular door not, you know, at the bottom of a swimming pool.

45462.base_text: “Hey, Niko?” I straightened up, keeping my voice steady. “Let’s go back.” I wanted to add I don’t like this or maybe I want to get the hell out of here right now, but some irrational fear gripped me that if I showed any weakness, he’d be the one who wanted to keep going down.

variants.text: “Hey, Niko?” I straightened up, keeping my voice steady. “Let’s go back.” I wanted to add I don’t like this or maybe I want to get the hell out of here right now, but some irrational fear gripped me that if I showed any weakness, he’d be the one who wanted to keep going down.

45462.base_text: Going deeper.

His voice was starting to seem unreal. I felt how tenuous a connection I had to him: a voice, the glints of his flashlight on the ceiling above the empty pool. Echoes and shadows. The distance between us seemed vast and growing vaster, maybe already unbridgeable.

variants.text: His voice was starting to seem unreal. I felt how tenuous a connection I had to him: a voice, the glints of his flashlight on the ceiling above the empty pool. Echoes and shadows. The distance between us seemed vast and growing vaster, maybe already unbridgeable.

45462.base_text: His voice was starting to seem unreal. I felt how tenuous a connection I had to him: a voice, the glints of his flashlight on the ceiling above the empty pool. Echoes and shadows. The distance between us seemed vast and growing vaster, maybe already unbridgeable. A strange nausea was creeping up on me, an unsettling dizziness, a turning, a skew.

45462.base_text: Coming from the other side of the closed door.

variants.text: Coming from the other side of the closed door.

45462.base_text: Something rattled up there, wood scraping wood. “There’s silverware in these drawers,” he called, as if he hadn’t heard me. “Cups in the cabinets too. Super seventies. Like the cups your grandma probably has, you know? I think Barbarella had these cups.”

variants.text: Something rattled up there, wood scraping wood. “There’s silverware in these drawers,” he called, as if he hadn’t heard me. “Cups in the cabinets too. Super seventies. Like the cups your grandma probably has, you know? I think Barbarella had these cups.”

45462.base_text: And then. Maybe I imagined this, between the weird echoes of that concrete pool bottom and the nerves I’d worked up. But I thought I heard muffled voices. Faint. Coming through the wall.

variants.text: And then. Maybe I imagined this, between the weird echoes of that concrete pool bottom and the nerves I’d worked up. But I thought I heard muffled voices. Faint. Coming through the wall.

45462.base_text: I remembered lying in bed as a kid, waiting to be tucked in, and the person I loved most in the world vanishing, between one blink and the next.

variants.text: I remembered lying in bed as a kid, waiting to be tucked in, and the person I loved most in the world vanishing, between one blink and the next.

45462.base_text: Coming from the other side of the closed door back out.

variants.text: Coming from the other side of the closed door back out.
